headline: Man Utd handed Carlos Baleba transfer timeline after opening January talks for £100m star
body: Manchester United are 'exploring' a move for Brighton & Hove Albion midfielder Carlos Baleba. The Red Devils have maintained an interest in the 21-year-old since last summer.
The £100million-rated Baleba's current Brighton deal runs until 2028 and has the option of a one-year extension. He is currently impressing for Cameroon at the Africa Cup of Nations in Morocco.

United spent heavily in the most recent summer transfer window, but it appears that the Reds' big spending under Ruben Amorim is not finished quite yet. Amorim wants midfield reinforcements as his No.1 priority to rebuild his squad.

Elliot Anderson of Nottingham Forest and Baleba are targets, but former United coach Rene Meulensteen told his old club recently to make Crystal Palace star Adam Wharton their top target next summer. “I’m a big fan of Wharton; I think he should be the number one priority for United next summer," the Dutchman said via BestNewBingoSites.
“He would be the perfect player to add to their squad, but I don’t think the move will be possible until next summer. He’s got great feet, and he is an effective and efficient player.

“He is always looking forward when he has the ball, which is a top-quality trait to have as a midfielder. He’s great in small spaces when he is being closed down quickly, and he always breaks the lines to find his unmarked teammates.

“His range of passing is second to none, and he has Premier League experience playing in the same formation that Amorim is playing at Man United. It’s an absolute no-brainer for United to sign Wharton next summer.”
Meanwhile, Reds boss Amorim suggested on Friday afternoon that there will not be any major reinforcements this month. He said: “The transfer window is not going to change.
“We have no conversations in this moment to have any change in the squad. There’s a process, there’s an idea that is going to continue.
“We are near the places of the Champions League, but we are near also for like eight teams behind us, so let’s focus on the next game. Just that. Our focus is to win the next game.”

headline: Man Utd predicted XI vs Leeds as Ruben Amorim handed major problem
body: Ruben Amorim will have some big decisions to make for his Manchester United starting lineup when they travel to Elland Road on Sunday. The Red Devils will be hoping to bounce back after dropping points against the Premier League's bottom side, Wolves.

Portuguese coach Amorim will have limited options to choose from for the trip to Yorkshire, however. United will take a depleted squad after Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire, Matthijs de Ligt and Mason Mount have all picked up injuries for the busiest period of the season.

To compound matters, Amorim can still not choose Bryan Mbeumo, Amad or Noussair Mazraoui after they progressed to the last-16 at AFCON with Cameroon, Morocco and Ivory Coast. United's boss relented in his tactical rigidity to change formation for a 1-0 win over Newcastle on Boxing Day.

A 1-1 draw against Wolves quickly dispelled any hint that Amorim would stick with a back four permanently. The 40-year-old may have it on his mind to swap back to the system when playing old rivals Leeds, however.
United's boss has admitted he is short of options. "You can see the squad, it is impossible and we cannot stretch the players that we don't have at the moment," he said.
"I will try to put together a team that is ready to cope with that. I will try to read the game and try to understand what I should do to help them."
Senne Lammens is an obvious choice in goal after starting 13 games on the bounce since making his debut in October. Those ahead of him are less certain.

But Amorim could be wise to switch to what worked so well against Newcastle and to utilise a back four. That could see Diogo Dalot, the increasingly impressive Ayden Heaven, Lisandro Martinez and Luke Shaw line up.

With more bodies in advanced positions, Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte should form the base of midfield, with few alternative options outside of academy products. Jack Fletcher was chosen from the bench last time out.
Ahead of them, Patrick Dorgu and Matheus Cunha can attack from the flanks. The former has transformed into a goal threat since being moved further up the field.
Joshua Zirkzee, widely linked to a move before January arrived, should offer some support to lead man Benjamin Sesko. The Dutch star will hope to get on the scoresheet once again.
Predicted Manchester United XI: Lammens; Dalot, Heaven, Martinez, Shaw; Casemiro, Ugarte; Dorgu, Zirkzee, Cunha; Sesko

headline: Man Utd set for Scott McTominay boost thanks to smart clause inserted into deal
body: Manchester United could be in for a significant financial boost due to a clever clause included in Scott McTominay's transfer to Napoli. The Scottish midfielder bid farewell to his childhood club in the summer of 2024, joining the Italian heavyweights in a €30.5m (£25.7m) deal that brought his two-decade-long relationship with United to an end.

The decision to sell McTominay raised eyebrows among fans given United's proud tradition of promoting academy graduates – but the move could prove profitable thanks to a sell-on clause included in the agreement.

As part of the terms, 10 per cent of any future sale from Napoli will go directly back to United. This could result in a substantial payout as the 29-year-old continues to carve out a reputation as one of Europe's leading midfielders, showcasing impressive form for both club and country.

Last year, McTominay was crowned player of the season in Italy following a stellar debut campaign where he played a pivotal role in helping Antonio Conte's team secure the Serie A title. In total, Napoli's No.8 netted 13 goals in 36 appearances across all competitions, earning him a nomination for the esteemed Ballon d'Or award won by Ousmane Dembele.

McTominay has also showcased his skills on the international stage with Scotland, a country he qualifies to represent through his father. In November, he scored a sensational overhead kick as Scotland triumphed over Denmark 4-2, securing the Tartan Army's place in the World Cup for the first time since 1998.

Transfermarkt now values McTominay at approximately €45m (£40m), with two-and-a-half years left on his contract with Napoli. The Italian club currently ranks third in Serie A, trailing leaders Inter by just two points.
A sale at that price would earn United an extra £4m due to their sell-on clause. However, this figure could potentially rise even further, with Napoli reportedly open to offers around £60m.

There are even whispers of a shock return to Old Trafford. CaughtOffside reports that United are considering re-signing McTominay as manager Ruben Amorim seeks to strengthen his thin midfield options.
The long-term futures of Kobbie Mainoo, Bruno Fernandes, Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte are uncertain, while injuries to Mainoo and captain Fernandes have left United lacking in midfield.

This shortage has forced Amorim to field 18 year old academy player Jack Fletcher for 45 minutes against Newcastle United on Boxing Day, and even deploy centre-back Lisandro Martinez in midfield during a match against Aston Villa. Other rumoured targets include Crystal Palace's standout player Adam Wharton, Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson and former United player James Garner, who is currently with Everton.

headline: Man Utd transfer talks confirmed amid '12-club scramble' for highly-rated youngster
body: Sheffield Wednesday are in talks to keep Manchester United youngster Harry Amass at the club until the end of the season. The 18-year-old's spell with the struggling Championship club is currently set to end following the clash against QPR at Loftus Road on Sunday lunchtime.
The on-loan star has been a shining light under difficult circumstances at Hillsborough. Amass has racked up 20 appearances for the Owls and barely missed a minute playing for boss Henrik Pedersen.

The young star's impressive performances have ensured that more clubs have taken an interest in his situation, with Wednesday's initial deal with United only having days left to run. Stoke and Millwall have been named as two of 12 clubs who have expressed an interest in landing Amass in January.

But the player has been very happy at Wednesday and United may decide not to disrupt his momentum mid-campaign. Wednesday boss Pedersen has confirmed that talks are underway for the Yorkshire club's November player of the month award winner. Communication is taking place between Wednesday, United and Amass' representative.
"There is a dialogue between the clubs and the agent, so I really hope that we can finalise something soon," Pedersen said on Friday. "Of course, we would love to keep him.

"He has done really, really well. He's 18-years-old, played so many games, which level he has played [at]. Of course the young guy has a lot to learn, but how he has played for us, it has been great."

The Owls are in a difficult position to undertake transfer business as they remain in administration and await a takeover. The club are in talks with the English Football League to establish what is possible in the coming weeks.

Currently, Wednesday are anticipated to be restricted to free agents and loan deals that do not require a fee. The club are operating under a fee restriction ban and are not allowed to sign any players for a fee until the end of the 2027 winter transfer window.

“I know there's a dialogue between the club and EFL now,” Pedersen “I hope that we get an answer very, very soon, and hopefully we can do some things so we can get some support to the players. At the minute there's a dialogue, but we need some clarity about what we can do.”

headline: Wayne Rooney pictured topless on Barbados beach as wife Coleen rocks bikini
body: Manchester United legend Wayne Rooney escaped the grey British weather for the blue skies of Barbados as he jetted off on a New Year’s holiday with wife Coleen.

The Rooneys were joined by their four sons - Kai, Kit, Klay, and Cass - but Wayne wasn't the only Old Trafford icon soaking up the Caribbean sun. Former team-mates Michael Carrick, Jonny Evans, and Darron Gibson were also spotted on the island.

The reunion brought together a wealth of silverware. Wayne and Carrick remain the only two English players to have won the Premier League, FA Cup, Champions League, League Cup, Community Shield, Europa League, and Club World Cup. Lucky fans spotted the group on the beach and managed to snap a few photos with the legendary set of players.
The Rooneys spent Christmas at their £20m mansion in Cheshire before boarding the flight to the tropics, and it was all smiles as they hit the sand for some well-earned relaxation.
The Manchester United legend opted against the traditional "cold dip" favoured by many Brits on New Year's Day. Instead, Wayne took a plunge into the warm Caribbean Sea.
Coleen Rooney stunned in a stripy bikini as she sipped a drink on the beach. It was only last year that Coleen finished as the runner-up on I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!
Wayne showed off his jet-ski skills while on holiday with his family. The 40-year-old seemed to be thoroughly enjoying his time away from the world of football punditry.

Coleen was all smiles as she worked on her tan in Barbados. Temperatures on the Caribbean island typically reach the high 20s during January - a far cry from the sub-zero conditions currently gripping England.
Rooney made the most of the winter sun as he relaxed by the water. The former United striker appeared to be holding a snus pouch while making his way back to the shore.
Coleen showed off her beach body in a stylish bikini while embracing the New Year’s spirit. The mother of four looked relaxed as she enjoyed a drink on the sand alongside her family.

headline: Ruben Amorim offers bleak Man Utd transfer outlook as he issues reality check
body: Ruben Amorim admits there are "no conversations" about potential arrivals at Manchester United in the January transfer window - and warned that the team need to look down as well as up over the coming weeks.

The club spent in excess of £200million of new arrivals in the summer, bolstering their frontline by bringing in the likes of Benjamin Sesko and Bryan Mbeumo. But there is unlikely to be any further new faces heading to Old Trafford during the New Year.

There remain obvious holes in the squad. A new central midfielder was on their radar in the summer but they lacked the finances to pursue the likes of Carlos Baleba or Elliot Anderson. Wing-backs remain a vital part of Amorim's philosophy and he is yet to address that position.

But the Portuguese head coach said on Boxing Day that sometimes he has "another idea" to director of football Jason Wilcox and the board when it comes to recruitment, but maintained that "common ground" must be found before a signing is made.

Amorim doesn't appear hopeful of new players arriving during January and whilst there is optimism at United, who sit sixth, making a charge towards the top four, he is also wise to the teams below them.

Amorim said: "The transfer window is not going to change. We have no conversations at this moment to have any change in the squad. There's a process, there's an idea that is going to continue. We are near the places of the Champions League, but we are also near like eight teams behind us. So let's focus on the next game, just that. Our focus is to win the next game."

Amorim has ruled out the possibility of Kobbie Mainoo leaving Manchester, which had been speculated. The midfielder had only start once this season with his standing not what it was under Erik ten Hag, when he was a regular in the middle of the pitch. Now he's often warming the bench.
There was rumoured interest from Napoli but Amorim insists Mainoo is the future of the club. He said recently: "Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity he has all the time.

"He played in different positions: he can do that [defensive midfield] position, he can play if we play with three, he can play like we play in the last game - the position of Mason Mount in this game (a number 10 who drops into midfield). So, he's going to be the future of Manchester United, that is my feeling. He just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days."

headline: Jamie Carragher makes cheeky Gary Neville dig as he calls for change in Man Utd stance
body: Jamie Carragher has quipped that one of his hopes for 2026 is for Gary Neville to stop predicting Manchester United will finish in the top four - but he isn't holding out much hope.

The ex-Liverpool defender has named several of his hopes for the upcoming year, which include another trophy for the Reds and success for his son, who is at Wigan, but also longed for Neville to stop with his constant United prediction.

He told The Telegraph: "Wigan Athletic to win promotion from League One into the Championship, Liverpool to win the Champions League, and for Gary Neville to stop predicting Manchester United are going to finish in the top four. At least two of those three have a chance of happening."

United have missed out on the top four in three of the past four seasons. Their only success coming in Erik ten Hag's first year when the Red Devils finished third. Since then they have come eighth before ending last year in 15th - a record low in the Premier League era.

Ruben Amorim's side began the year inconsistently but even in recent months Neville has reiterated his stance that United could sneak into the top four. That came after they'd beaten Liverpool at Anfield with the Merseyside outfit - and some of their rivals - enduring dips in form.

He said: "United should really be thinking that if they can get it right - Tottenham as well but it's tougher for tham with European games - they should be thinking around top four. They really should, because there's no one grabbing it at this moment. You look at Chelsea, Tottenham, who don't look sure, Liverpool don't look sure... it's there for it's there for the taking. It's about consistency."

As things stand United sit in sixth, three points behind Liverpool who occupy fourth spot. Neville has bemoaned several missed opportunities in recent weeks with Bournemouth and Wolves both leaving Old Trafford with a point.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo makes final decision on Man Utd exit in shock transfer U-turn
body: Kobbie Mainoo remains determined to make a success of his career at Manchester United despite a hugely challenging 13 months under Ruben Amorim which has seen him slip down the Old Trafford pecking order.

The academy star burst onto the scene under Erik ten Hag and within a year of making his debut was playing for England in the final of the Euros. But since the Dutchman's axing his stock has fallen significantly with Amorim preferring other options. Mainoo has started in only 16 of Amorim’s 61 matches in charge of United and last made the starting XI when he played during the humiliating Carabao Cup Cup exit to League Two Grimsby in August - which will have done little to aid his cause for more involvement.

The Sun reports that the working relationship between Mainoo’s camp and Amorim was strained even before the midfielder’s half-brother wore a ‘Free Kobbie Mainoo’ T-shirt at Old Trafford during the 4-4 draw with Bournemouth last month - which again won't have gone down well with the manager.

Despite all that - and links to other clubs - those close to the 20-year-old United star insist he is determined to revive his Old Trafford career and fulfil his potential at the club where he's been since a child.

United blocked Mainoo’s request to leave on loan in the summer and, despite talk resurfacing ahead of January, Amorim again made it clear that the midfielder would not be departing Old Trafford, even temporarily. Despite his lack of minutes the Portuguese head coach has maintained that he is the future of the club.

Mainoo’s contract expires in 2027 but United have the option of an additional year - meaning there is no hope of the player's camp attempting to force a move away but using that to their advantage. That said, Mainoo declined United’s opening offer of a new contract at the start of 2025.

The England international was only 17 when he signed his last deal in February 2023. Since then Mainoo has enjoyed huge highs - he played and scored in an FA Cup final and was crucial for England at the Euros.

His lack of minutes is now counting against him. His hopes of going to a second major tournament with the Three Lions is in jeopardy with Thomas Tuchel currently unlikely to pick him for the World Cup in the summer.
Mainoo was one of eight players absent for United’s underwhelming 1-1 draw with Wolves, who claimed their third point of the season at Old Trafford on Tuesday night.

headline: opinionLiverpool, Man Utd and Arsenal handed transfer verdicts as January window demands made
body: The January transfer window has opened and all 20 Premier League clubs will feel they have clear priorities. However, some may be more desperate than others to get deals done.

Arsenal sit top of the pile at the halfway point in the season, but they and closest challengers Manchester City could both be busy. At the other end of the table, those battling against relegation may call on new faces to help their cause.
In between, you have the likes of Liverpool and Manchester United. Both will arguably be disappointed by their current league standing, even if United are faring better than they were last season.

Arsenal extended their lead at the top of the table midweek but Riccardo Calafiori and Declan Rice both missed the game through injury and defensive cover looks like being the highest priority. Rennes centre-back Jeremy Jacquet could be a good option for the present and future, though there is likely to be competition from elsewhere in the league.

Depth in attack could be the order of the day, especially if Villa are able to get out-of-favour loanee Harvey Elliott off the books. Newcastle forward William Osula could fit the bill, with earlier reports of a Frankfurt move for the Danish star dimming.

Much will depend on whether Bournemouth cash in early on Antoine Semenyo but that looks more likely than not. Oscar Bobb would make sense, especially if the Norwegian drops further down the Manchester City pecking order with Semenyo moving to the Etihad Stadium.

Central midfield could end up being a priority for Keith Andrews' Bees with Vitaly Janelt and Mathias Jensen both out of contract this summer. Quinten Timber, brother of Arsenal defender Jurrien, has been identified as a potential target to bring quality and high level experience after playing in the Champions League for Feyenoord.

Brighton may in part find themselves seeking out a long-term successor to Carlos Baleba, with the expectation being that there will be renewed interest in the £100m-rated star in the summer. Boca Juniors star Milton Delgado, who reached the Under-20 World Cup final with his country earlier this year, would fit the Seagulls' tried-and-tested approach of buying young talents with high ceilings.

Josh Cullen's season-ending ACL injury means a new midfielder could well be high on the Clarets' shopping list. If Liverpool are prepared to sanction a loan for Wataru Endo, the Japan star could suit Burnley's plan of loans rather than expensive gambles.
Chelsea's first target is a new manager after Enzo Maresca's departure. Liam Rosenior looks to be the front-runner, with sales and loans perhaps a bigger priority when it comes to players.
Palace's first deal is effectively done, with Brennan Johnson on his way from Spurs. A new centre-back could also be added, with an expectation that Marc Guehi leaves in the summer.
A new striker is on Everton's radar, with Thierno Barry flattering to deceive since his summer move. Ivan Toney is expected to prove too expensive but Jorgen Strand Larsen has been mooted.

Marco Silva is hopeful of adding depth to his Fulham squad, especially in attack. United States international Ricardo Pepi looks to have a chance of moving to West London, continuing the Cottagers' rich tradition of American stars.

Leeds spent big in the summer but may feel they need one or two new faces to bolster the fight against relegation. Harry Wilson has been mentioned, and the Welshman is out of contract in the summer so Fulham may entertain bids despite his impressive form this term.
A new centre-back looks important given Giovanni Leoni's ACL injury. Marc Guehi doesn't look likely to leave Crystal Palace until the summer but Liverpool may decide time is of the essence.
An easy one here. Antoine Semenyo adds genuine Premier League quality to an already healthy front line and a £65m fee would feel like a snip if he makes the difference in the hunt for trophies.

United are likely to make a marquee midfield signing in the summer but a cheaper January option is also possible. James Garner ticks the boxes in price and quality, as well as the less tangible 'knows the club' factor.

A new midfielder would allow Newcastle to cash in on Joe Willock, with the former Arsenal man potentially allowed to leave in search of regular minutes. Kees Smit of AZ Alkmaar has been attracting Premier League interest and Newcastle looks to be the most likely destination.

Forest are keen to strengthen down the left flank, while longer-term they may eventually need to replace Elliot Anderson if a big summer bid comes in. On the left, a reunion for manager Sean Dyche and Everton's Dwight McNeil makes sense if the Merseyside club sanction an exit.

Sunderland were very active over the summer and are likely to be less so in January, but a winger could yet arrive despite Brennan Johnson opting against a move north. Paris FC's Ilan Kebbal has been mentioned after impressing in Ligue 1 with six goals and four assists in 16 appearances.

With Johnson leaving, Spurs have money to spend and may well put it towards a new forward of their own. They looked at Man City's Savinho over the summer and could try again this month, but Cameroon star Karl Etta Eyong is another option with a greater immediate goal threat.

A new striker is high on West Ham's radar, with suggestions they could even sign two frontmen after allowing Niclas Fullkrug to join AC Milan on loan. Lazio's Taty Castellanos has struggled with injury this term, hence his low goal tally, but the Argentine looks like an option for the struggling Hammers.

With a miracle needed to avoid relegation, Wolves may need to look long-term. It's hard to see Jorgen Strand Larsen staying put too long, so a move for Sam Surridge - who scored 24 goals in MLS in 2025 - could help them prepare for a likely season in the second tier.

headline: Man Utd news: Marcus Rashford uncertainty emerges as on loan star returns to Old Trafford
body: Manchester United face a pivotal month as the January transfer window begins to unfold. Ruben Amorim’s side are in the hunt for a Champions League spot but may need reinforcements to get themselves over the line.

The team have provided reasons to be optimistic throughout the season, overcoming tough moments to stay in contention for the top four. United will hope to bounce back from their underwhelming draw with Wolves and reassert themselves with a positive result against Leeds on Sunday.

Ahead of the transfer window, Amorim’s side were linked with several high-profile midfielders but the Portuguese coach has been given an unexpected squad boost at the start of the New Year. Here is a closer look at some of the biggest stories surrounding Old Trafford.

Marcus Rashford is relishing his loan spell at Barcelona but fresh doubts have arisen over whether the England international will remain at the club permanently. The 28-year-old has made it clear that he wishes to stay with the Catalan giants beyond this season.

The United loanee has showcased his quality in Spain, scoring seven and registering 11 assists in 24 games. However, Spanish outlet Mundo Deportivo reports that Rashford is one of three Barcelona players facing an uncertain future at the Camp Nou.

Rashford, alongside Robert Lewandowski and defender Andreas Christensen, is among a trio of stars whose Barcelona deals end in the summer. It is claimed that the United forward has had positive feedback from Barcelona but it is not yet a formality that his parent club will trigger his £26million buy clause.
The Spanish club will reportedly attempt to lower the agreed fee, with Barcelona’s financial constraints well-publicised. It is added that Rashford could improve his pressing and defensive work.

Despite the speculation, Rashford shared a positive message on social as he welcomed in the New Year. He wrote: "As 2025 comes to a close, I'm grateful for a year of change and self reflection. Stepping into 2026 feeling excited, motivated, and ready to be ambitious both in sport and life.”

Manchester United have confirmed that midfielder Toby Collyer has been recalled from his loan spell at West Bromwich Albion. The 21-year-old made 12 Championship appearances before returning to Old Trafford.

Collyer has been sidelined since picking up an injury in November, leading to his loan spell being cut short. A United club statement explained that the academy graduate had returned to focus on his fitness, while also potentially adding to the options at Amorim’s disposal.

The defensive midfielder featured 13 times for United last term. However, he was unexpectedly called out by Amorim recently as the United boss made a wider point about some of the club’s youngsters being promoted to the first team too early in their development.

"He (Collyer) played (for United)," Amorim said in December. "He's from the academy. He played here. He went to West Bromwich. He's not playing. He played for Manchester United. So sometimes it's not because he's from the academy or whatever. It's the situation, what's happened.”

headline: Man Utd were forced into transfer plan U-turn just hours after January window opened
body: The January transfer window is officially open, and it could be another busy one for Manchester United. The Red Devils are in the market for a new midfielder, while the likes of Kobbie Mainoo and Joshua Zirkzee may be on their way out of Old Trafford.

The winter window gives clubs the opportunity to improve their squads and kick on up the table. But sometimes managers are also caught out by injuries, surprise bids and loan recalls, causing them to dip into the market when they didn't necessarily plan to.
United know more about this than some others. They were forced to get busy in January 2023 after Martin Dubravka was re-called by parent club Newcastle United.
Dubravka penned a season-long deal in summer 2022 and was introduced to provide competition for David de Gea but made only two appearances under Erik ten Hag.
Due to these limited minutes, Newcastle saw fit to re-call him just hours after the January window had opened, leaving United short.
A United statement read: "We would like to thank Martin for his contribution during his time with our club, and wish him all the best for the future."
Signing a goalkeeper certainly wasn't part of the transfer plan that year, but it became a priority after Dubravka unexpectedly left the club.

Five days later, United got Crystal Palace shot-stopper Jack Butland on board at Old Trafford on a short-term contract to provide cover. Once he returned to Palace, Butland would then sign for Scottish club Rangers, who he now plays for.

In the summer of 2023, De Gea's own reign in between the sticks at United came to an end, having been at the club since 2011. The Red Devils then acquired the services of Andre Onana and Altay Bayindir.

Onana was introduced to serve as the number one goalkeeper but he has now been shipped out to Trabzonspor on loan, with Senne Lammens the main man. Bayindir now serves as his back-up, with Tom Heaton third-choice.

Lammens has been solid in goal for United, who seem to have finally found their long-term successor to De Gea. He picked up the Player of the Match away in Tuesday night's 1-1 draw with Wolverhampton Wanderers.
Discussing Lammens' switch to Manchester from Royal Antwerp, the goalkeeper's agent claimed that United originally planned to keep Onana at the club to mentor Lammens.
Speaking to Belgian outlet HBVL, Mark Volders said: "Those critical voices... the big problem was that they expected a very well-known name, like [Gianluigi] Donnarumma or [Emiliano] Martínez.

"But actually, for a long time, the intention within United was for Onana to stay and for Senne to be given time to adjust. Ultimately, they changed their tune right at the very end, Onana left, and fully embraced Senne. But in hindsight, you can only say that United was right about that."
United will hope they don't have to unexpectedly dive into the market this January, while there are eight names on a shortlist of midfielders who could arrive at Old Trafford this month.

headline: Arsenal and Man City's next 5 Premier League fixtures as Gunners handed title boost
body: The New Year is upon us and that means it’s only a matter of months before the Premier League trophy will be hoisted into the air once again. The only mystery remains over the identity of the team who will be lifting it.
As it stands, Arsenal are the favourites to be crowned come the end of the campaign. Mikel Arteta's side have enjoyed a brilliant start to the 2025-26 campaign.

Their dominant 4-1 win against Aston Villa has left them four clear at the top of the table. And should that be a position they keep until May, they will end a long wait that has seen them go over two decades without a league title.

They do however have one issue and that’s Manchester City. Pep Guardiola’s side have made winning the Premier League a habit. However, they could only earn a point in their first outing of 2026 after drawing 0-0 with Sunderland.

Despite Champions League, Carabao Cup and FA Cup fixtures presenting the Gunners with a few distractions, they will no doubt be prioritising their Premier League title push. Their first fixture in 2026 sees them up against Bournemouth away from home.

They then follow that up with a home game against Liverpool just a few days later. While Arne Slot’s side have not been at their imperious best this season, a clash against the reigning champions still presents a stern challenge.

A trip to Nottingham Forest is then their next assignment nine days later, while a Sunday showdown with Manchester United at the Emirates comes towards the end of the month. Arsenal round off January with an away clash with a resurgent Leeds at Elland Road.

headline: Man Utd make surprise transfer decision as Ruben Amorim U-turns on youngster
body: Manchester United have recalled midfielder Toby Collyer from his loan spell at West Brom to ease their injury woes.

The 21-year-old made 12 appearances for the Baggies during his loan in the Championship, although just three of those were starts, with the midfielder him injured since the end of November. He's been edging towards a first-team return and could now provide cover for Ruben Amorim.

Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount and Kobbie Mainoo all missed the 1-1 draw against Wolves on Tuesday and the decision to bring Collyer back to Manchester may well be motivated by a desire to have more options.
The midfielder made his debut for the club in August 2024 and made 13 appearances last season, but was the subject of critical comments from Amorim recently.

The United boss has been called out for making little use of the academy but suggested several young talents, Collyer among them, were promoted to the first-team too early having played in the ill-fated Erik ten Hag era.

"He (Collyer) played (for United)," Amorim said in December. "He's from the academy. He played here. He went to West Bromwich. He's not playing. He played for Manchester United. So sometimes it's not because he's from the academy or whatever. It's the situation, what's happened.

"I don't know what is going to be the future (for Mainoo). Let's see after this match. Amass is now struggling in the Championship. Chido (Obi) is not always a starter in under-21s. All these guys played when a lot of people were saying sack the manager!"

Despite those comments Collyer is highly though of in Manchester, so much so that the club refused to consider him as part of any deal that could've seen the Red Devils sign Carlos Baleba from Brighton.

There had been reports suggesting Collyer could be used as a sweetener to sign Baleba back in the summer. The youngster had progressed through Brighton's academy before leaving in 2022 and the Seagulls had been keen to bring him back to the south coast, where he is from.
Collyer is regarded as one of the finest midfielders in the country and United were surprised they had the chance to sign him - but they were delighted that they did.
His stint at the Hawthorns failed to aid his development as the club and the player had expected and he will now continue his career at Carrington.

headline: Man Utd legend's three strikes that made him never speak to team-mate again
body: Andy Cole has opened up about his feud with former Manchester United team-mate Teddy Sheringham. Despite their shared success at Old Trafford, the two strikers were known for their frosty relationship.
Cole, who moved to Manchester from Newcastle after a record-breaking season, was instrumental in United's 1999 treble-winning campaign and helped secure five Premier League titles.

However, his relationship with Sheringham was marked by tension and animosity. Now, the 54-year-old has revisited the roots of their dispute, offering fresh insight into this well-documented rivalry, including the three incidents that led to their silence.
"It started when I was playing for England," Cole said on In The Mixer, brought to you by Sky Bet. "I was going to make my England debut.

"He [Sheringham] was he was coming off and he just snubbed me on the line. So straight away, my head just falls off. I remember growing up as a kid watching England, whoever made their debut, anyone who came off for them would always make a big beeline for that person coming on.

"Debuts are supposed to mean a hell of a lot to whoever it is, whatever respective country you're going to play for. To know that I didn't get someone respecting me on my debut, it was just playing with my head straight away."

Sheringham's arrival at Old Trafford in 1997 saw the pair's relationship deteriorate further. Cole recalled: "When he joined Man United, I remember sitting there and saying to myself, 'Oh my gosh, problems, problems.'

"So I've walked in on the first day and I've gone to the dressing room and the boys are absolutely hammering me. Calling us best mates and everything like that. Then pre-season, it was in Milan or somewhere like that and he said something to me. I'm like, 'Do you know how long I've been at Man United now? I mean, I think I know how to play.'

"That kind of set the time bomb off. Then we played Bolton and it ended 1-1. He said the Bolton goal was my fault. I lost it. Proper lost it. I'm usually the last person off the pitch. I don't rush down the tunnel or anything like that. But I remember then I was the first one down the tunnel.

"I ran to the dressing room and I'm waiting for him to come in. Then it goes off in the dressing room and then the manager pulls me in. He said, 'This can't go on. I know you two don't get on, but I can't condone that in the dressing room.'

headline: Man Utd boss Ruben Amorim gets mixed news from AFCON over Bryan Mbeumo and Amad
body: Manchester United won't be seeing their Africa Cup of Nations trio any time soon - but Ruben Amorim can at least take heart from the fact they are being managed carefully while on international duty.

United have been seriously depleted in recent matches, with Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui away at AFCON, while Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire, Matthijs de Ligt and Mason Mount have all picked up injuries. It has coincided with the busiest period of the season, forcing Amorim to adapt.

Those adaptions were going well when a much-changed side held on to record a 1-0 win over Newcastle on Boxing Day. But a 1-1 draw against the Premier League's bottom side, Wolves, quickly dispelled any hint of optimism, potentially sending Amorim back to the drawing board.

United were pretty uninspired in attack against Wolves and needed a fluky deflected effort from Joshua Zirkzee to find the back of the net. How the Portuguese boss must have wished he could call upon Mbeumo and Amad.

He therefore won't have been delighted to see that Morocco, Cameroon and Ivory Coast all made it out of the group stages at AFCON. Mazraoui, Mbeumo and Amad are now looking forward to knockout matches in Morocco, rather than United's game against Leeds on Sunday.

Cameroon came from 1-0 down to beat Mozambique 2-1 on New Year's Eve, while defending champions Ivory Coast also mounted a comeback to beat Gabon 3-2 and top Group F. The results mean that Cameroon will play South Africa in the last 16, while Ivory Coast will face Burkina Faso. Morocco had already booked their knockout match against Tanzania on Sunday.

Mid-season tournaments are always a tricky thing to negotiate for club managers, who wish their players well but ultimately have selfish motives. They want them back as quickly as possible and without any injuries.

So Amorim will have been pleased to see Mbeumo taken off at half-time in Cameroon's win against Mozambique - not because of an injury, but to manage his minutes. Amad, meanwhile, started Ivory Coast's game on the bench and came on as a 76th-minute substitute.

Morocco and Cameroon play their last 16 games on Sunday - the same day United travel to Elland Road to face Leeds - while Ivory Coast are next in action on Tuesday. It means that, in theory, if their national sides lose, Mazraoui and Mbeumo could be back with United in time for their trip to Turf Moor to play Burnley on Wednesday, January 7.
Amad, however, wouldn't be back until the FA Cup third-round tie against Brighton on Sunday, January 11, at the earliest, if Ivory Coast are beaten by Burkina Faso.

Amorim will therefore have to continue to put his faith in United's academy players, who have been given rare opportunities to play first-team minutes. Jack Fletcher and Bendito Mantato came off the bench against Wolves, while Tyler Fredricson got minutes in the win over Newcastle.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson's January transfer warning as Man Utd eye up eight-man shortlist
body: Sir Alex Ferguson warned against clubs using the January transfer window to find a quick fix. Manchester United have been linked with several deals in the New Year, but the legendary manager advised teams to avoid big-money moves during the winter window.

Ruben Amorim’s side are chasing a return to Champions League football but currently sit two points off fourth-placed Liverpool, who could extend the gap with a win over Leeds on Thursday night. Though there have been signs of improvement across the campaign, United’s recent stalemate with Wolves reminded fans of their team’s shortcomings.

The transfer window offers Amorim an opportunity to strengthen his squad, both in the short and long term. However, Ferguson previously explained why he believed making major signings in January was not worth the risk.

In 2012, Ferguson stated that no marquee January signing had ever been an instant success. "I've never seen it work, a player come in January, sign for big money and settle before the start of next season,” the United boss told The Independent.
He added: "To go into the market in January you never get full value, people think you're desperate so ask for more."

Ferguson largely stuck to his own advice throughout his tenure, despite two of his best-ever signings both arriving in January 2006. Nemanja Vidic and Patrice Evra cost a combined £12.5million from their respective clubs but did not immediately establish themselves as stars, taking time to settle in at Old Trafford.

While the success rate of major January signings is mixed, there are notable exceptions, including United skipper Bruno Fernandes. Focusing on the current transfer window, United are claimed to have assembled an eight-man shortlist of centre midfielders to bolster Amorim’s team.

The Daily Mail reports that Nottingham Forest ’s Elliot Anderson is top of the club’s wishlist, though a deal is unlikely as his team continue to battle relegation. Brighton’s highly-rated Carlos Baleba and Crystal Palace star Adam Wharton were both heavily linked with United in the summer.

England international Conor Gallagher has previously been touted with swapping Atletico Madrid for Old Trafford. Meanwhile, Everton’s James Garner has also been linked with a return to his boyhood club.

Other options mentioned in the report are Bournemouth's Tyler Adams, Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes and Portugal international Ruben Neves, who currently plays for Al-Hilal. Whether United opt to spend big in January remains to be seen but Amorim has been short of midfield options in recent weeks.

Injuries to Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo saw United start with Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte in midfield against Wolves, with youngster Jack Fletcher being introduced at half-time. Ferguson would support Amorim utilising the club’s academy talent to solve the club’s midfield issue, rather than seeking an expensive solution in January.

One of the only exceptions Ferguson made during his reign was to sign Louis Saha from Fulham in early 2004, who instantly began repaying his £12.85m fee with seven goals in 14 games. Experienced striker Henrik Larsson was also brought in on a short-term loan as Ferguson sought an immediate boost in 2007. However, the vast majority of his January dealings focused on long-term prospects.

Wilfried Zaha became the last signing of the Ferguson era when he completed his £10m move from Crystal Palace in January 2013. Viewed as a player for the future, he was loaned back to Palace. In the following campaign, Zaha made just four appearances during his sole season at United before rejoining Palace permanently that summer.

headline: Eight Man Utd January transfer targets including two £100m stars and four who could leave
body: The January transfer window is shaping up to be an intriguing one for Manchester United. Over the past weeks and months, several high-profile stars have been linked with moves to the Theatre of Dreams, while a number of established squad members look to be nearing the exit door.
Historically, United's mid-season transfers have been hit and miss. For every game-changing arrival like Nemanja Vidic or Bruno Fernandes, there has been an Alexis Sanchez or a Dong Fangzhuo.

Ruben Amorim's squad will aim to carry their relatively strong end-of-2025 momentum into the New Year and start the campaign strongly, as the club pursues its first top-four finish in three seasons. Navigating the January window successfully could be crucial - not just for turning United's season into a memorable one, but also in cementing Amorim's long-term position at the club.

Antoine Semenyo has been in sensational form at Bournemouth this season, attracting serious interest from United as a potential solution to their lack of width and firepower up top. His ability to take on defenders and finish clinically has boosted his profile significantly in recent months, with a release clause making him an appealing mid-season target.

However, United seem to have slipped behind in the race, with rivals Manchester City closing in on his signature. Reports suggest a deal at the Etihad Stadium could be completed this week, meaning United supporters might see the Ghanaian in blue rather than red this winter.

Crystal Palace's midfielder has become one of the Premier League's most wanted deep-lying playmakers due to his outstanding passing and calmness under pressure. Amorim reportedly sees him as the perfect 'metronome' to control the tempo of his 3-4-3 system and facilitate transitions from the defensive third.

Signing Wharton will not be cheap, with Palace expected to demand at least £70million for their star - and possibly much more to sanction a mid-season transfer. While United's interest is genuine, a January deal is considered difficult, as the Eagles aim to retain their squad until summer.

Carlos Baleba has impressed United scouts as a high-energy, all-action midfielder capable of rejuvenating the current squad. His capacity to break up play and surge forward with the ball fits perfectly with the high-pressing requirements of modern United football.

Brighton are known as tough negotiators and are likely to insist on a fee close to £100m given his long-term promise, as they did in the summer. While United are said to be eager to secure the Cameroonian, Brighton's valuation may make a move this month unlikely.

After a breakthrough season at Nottingham Forest, Elliot Anderson has become a top midfield target for several leading clubs. His technical skill in tight areas and tireless work rate make him stand out in both the Premier League and Thomas Tuchel's England squad.

Forest are reportedly seeking at least £100m for the former Newcastle United player and are unlikely to consider a mid-season sale. Coupled with strong interest from Manchester City and Chelsea, a January move appears highly challenging.

Stuttgart's playmaker has been identified as a refined alternative for United's midfield, offering exceptional football intelligence and advanced ball progression. Excelling in the Bundesliga and for Germany, he is viewed as ready to step straight into a top European club.

Stiller reportedly has a release clause around £34million, effective in 2026. United could see him as a cost-efficient option compared with other targets - a consideration made even more relevant given injuries and possible departures in their midfield.

In what would be both a sentimental and strategic acquisition, United are reportedly exploring a return for former academy graduate James Garner from Everton to strengthen squad depth. Garner has developed into a dependable Premier League performer, whose energy and tactical awareness would offer a low-risk midfield solution.
Garner's contract runs until the end of the season, allowing the Red Devils to potentially secure him at a reduced cost if Everton are unwilling to lose him for free in the summer.

Ex-Chelsea midfielder Conor Gallagher has struggled for playing time at Atletico Madrid this season and is reportedly eager to return to England to secure a spot in the 2026 World Cup squad. United value his 'engine' and Premier League experience, seeing him as an immediate boost to midfield intensity.

Atletico are understood to be willing to consider a sale at around £30m, though United may be able to negotiate a lower price given Gallagher's limited appearances this term. It may not be a headline-grabbing move, but Gallagher could be a clever addition for a United side short on energy and depth in central midfield.

Eintracht Frankfurt wing-back Nathaniel Brown has come onto United's radar as a solution for their ongoing left-sided issues. His pace and ability to offer width in a back-five make him a highly tactical fit for Amorim's system.

As an emerging Bundesliga talent, the 22-year-old could cost around £50m, representing a high-risk option given his lack of top-level experience. Still, with United in need of elite wing-backs, Brown could be a gamble worth pursuing.

Although hailed as one of United's brightest prospects in 2024, Kobbie Mainoo has dropped out of Amorim's first-team plans and is expected to leave in January. The midfielder wants regular playing time, especially with the World Cup approaching, and is reportedly pushing for a loan.

Several top European clubs are monitoring his situation should a temporary move be approved. However, with United short in midfield, the club are hesitant to allow him to leave without first finding a replacement. A loan appears likely, but an incoming signing may need to come first.
Following a difficult spell on the sidelines and limited first-team opportunities, Tyrell Malacia is widely expected to depart this winter to restart his career.
With his contract expiring in summer, United are keen to sell rather than lose him for free - and are reportedly open to bids as low as £3m for the Dutchman.

Joshua Zirkzee has struggled to replicate the goal-scoring form that prompted his move from Bologna. Reports indicate AS Roma have made a formal loan proposal with an obligation to buy, as the striker is keen to return to Serie A.
United are reviewing the offer but may wait until a replacement is secured before approving the move. This transfer looks highly likely, with all parties aligned on a fresh start.

Despite his recent arrival, speculation suggests Ugarte may not fit the specific midfield style Amorim wants. While still a top-class ball-winner, interest from other European clubs has raised questions over his long-term future at Old Trafford.
United are open to selling, but only for the right fee. Turkish giants Galatasaray are among the interested clubs and are reportedly preparing a loan-plus-option-to-buy bid this month.

headline: Man Utd news: Ruben Amorim opens up on trust problems as player explains why he quit club
body: Manchester United will hope to start the New Year on a positive note as the club prepare to face Leeds United this weekend. Ruben Amorim's side are set to renew their rivalry with the Yorkshire club at Elland Road on Sunday.

The turn of the year also marks the beginning of the January transfer window. United have been linked with several deals, both incomings and outgoings, as Amorim seeks to improve his team in their pursuit of a Champions League place.

Whether a change will come through the manager placing more trust in youth prospects or refining his squad in the transfer market remains to be seen. However, one player has revealed why he chose to leave Old Trafford during Amorim’s reign. Here is a closer look at some of the biggest stories surrounding the club.

Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim admitted that he purposely avoided bringing on more academy starlets as his team chased a winning goal against Wolves. The club endured a disappointing 1-1 draw on Tuesday night, with Wolves picking up just their third point of the campaign.

The United boss opted to replace goalscorer Joshua Zirkzee with young midfielder Jack Fletcher at the interval, with Leny Yoro and debutant Bendito Mandato being brought on later in the game. However, Amorim avoided utilising the attacking options of Shea Lacey and Chido Obi as he felt they would further disrupt his team, given United's lengthy list of absentees.
“It's completely different and you know that when there is a lot of new people in different positions and you put one young kid, he will struggle,” Amorim explained.

"It's completely different when you have a base, everything is working well and you can give minutes to a young kid. You look at the game and you understand clearly and you see our team and you know that you are going to struggle in certain aspects and I think that was what happened during the game."

Rasmus Hojlund has revealed what convinced him to leave Manchester United this summer. The striker had previously been determined to stay at Old Trafford before securing a deadline day loan move to Napoli.

It has proven to be a beneficial switch for Hojlund, who has already bettered his league goal tally from last season. The 22-year-old, who has scored six in 12 Serie A matches, has shared what eventually persuaded him to leave United.

When asked why he changed his decision, Hojlund told Sports Illustrated: "United made it very quite clear that I wasn't part of their plans for this year, coming into the season. And with no European football, I think Napoli saw an opportunity to go and get me. As soon as I heard of their interest, I made it quite obvious to my camp and the people around me that I only wanted to go there.”

headline: Marcus Rashford snubs Man Utd in telling message amid Barcelona transfer wait
body: Marcus Rashford has shared a New Year's message without even so much as mentioning Manchester United. The 28-year-old is currently flourishing during his loan spell with Barcelona, netting seven goals and providing 11 assists across 24 outings in all competitions.

It's been an incredibly productive year for Rashford, who earned a recall to the England squad on the back of his impressive form during temporary spells at both Aston Villa and Barcelona. Rashford has managed to capture the best moments of his year in nine photographs on Instagram, predominantly featuring him in a Barcelona shirt.

In his message, he wrote: "As 2025 comes to a close, I'm grateful for a year of change and self reflection. Stepping into 2026 feeling excited, motivated, and ready to be ambitious both in sport and life. MR14 [red and blue heart emoji]."
Whilst there's no direct reference to United, there is a Villa photograph that shows the spot-kick he converted against Manchester City, which clearly indicates his pride in that particular moment.
Spain's winter break has meant Rashford and Barcelona have enjoyed an extended rest period - with their most recent match taking place 10 days ago on Sunday, December 21.

Rashford started that 2-0 triumph on the subs bench, but he then entered the action for the closing 28 minutes. Hansi Flick chose to field Raphinha, Fermin Lopez and Lamine Yamal as his attacking three behind the striker, with the same trio getting the nod from the start in the Champions League victory against Eintracht Frankfurt.

Rashford subsequently provided an assist after coming off the bench in that match. Despite being overlooked on two occasions, Rashford responded to the team selection decisions in exemplary fashion, according to Flick.

He said: "I try to speak to every player when they are not selected and the last time I checked with him he replied me; 'Boss, you don't have to tell me about your decisions'," Flick said on Rashford. "'The most important thing is the team. We have to win the three points. The rest is not that important'.

headline: Ruben Amorim's January transfer predictions are good and bad news for Manchester United
body: January is arguably one of the toughest months for Premier League managers. Not only have we reached the halfway stage of the season and fixture congestion begins to ramp up with the FA Cup returning for the top flight, teams also have to negotiate a transfer window.

For Manchester United, the January transfer window very rarely offers much optimism for supporters. In their recent history, the Reds have chosen not to make big transfer statements midway through the season, even when new additions were desperately needed.

When everyone knew United needed to add a centre-forward to their attack under Erik ten Hag, the Reds were left to settle with the arrival of Wout Weghorst in the January transfer window. While the Dutchman had performed well for his national team, the Premier League was clearly too big a step for the target man.
Of course, clubs like United have to be wary of overspending in the mid-season window. It appears Ruben Amorim will watch the 2026 window go by without making any alterations to his team.

He explained in his pre-Leeds press conference: "We have no conversations in this moment about having any change in the squad. There is a process, there is an idea that is going to continue." This prediction is bad news for United.
It is clear to United fans that at least one change should be made this month. In terms of outgoings, Joshua Zirkzee is obviously not a player who Amorim has much faith in.

His substitution against Wolves at half time, despite scoring, was a clear sign the forward has no future at the club. Sadly for Zirkzee, he is not good enough to lead the line for United and, playing deeper in the No.10 role, he is not better than Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo, Amad or Mason Mount.

The right thing to do in the January transfer window is to let Zirkzee leave, especially with Roma keen. If that deal was done, there would have been space available to add a striker to the squad who could compete with Benjamin Sesko.

However, the claim of no changes being made to the squad in the January transfer window suggests this plan is not under consideration. This is a blow for the Reds as they look to gain some consistency while pushing for a place in the top four.

Fortunately for United, there was some positive news to close out the press conference. Amorim was asked whether he expected any of his players to come to him and request their exit from Old Trafford this month. "No," Amorim replied. "I don't expect them to come to me and ask anything."

If this proves to be the case, it would be great news for the Reds. One of the main fears in the January transfer window is that Kobbie Mainoo will push hard for an exit in an attempt to play regularly before the World Cup.

Mainoo leaving in January would be a disaster for the Reds. Not only would United be losing one of their best academy graduates in recent years, they would also be left painfully short in the midfield. Even if Mainoo only left on loan, a temporary exit would still see him take a step closer to a possible permanent exit.

Injuries to Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes have proven the Reds are lacking playmakers in this squad. The Manuel Ugarte and Casemiro combination does not offer much in the way of creativity, that much is clear.
United cannot afford for Mainoo to leave. If he is looking to stay in Manchester and fight for his place, that can only be good news for the club.

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim issues Manchester United January transfer update
body: Ruben Amorim said there are no conversations ongoing with the Manchester United hierarchy about signing new players in the January transfer window, despite the club being in the fight to qualify for next season's Champions League.

United are sixth at the halfway stage of the Premier League campaign, level on points with Chelsea in fifth and only three points shy of Liverpool in fourth, but Amorim insisted that wouldn't change the plans the club have made.

Amorim has previously suggested that United would consider making a move in January if the conditions were right and they were open to activating Antoine Semenyo's £65million release clause at Bournemouth, only for the attacker to opt for Manchester City.

But the United head coach has now claimed there are no active conversations with director of football Jason Wilcox or chief executive Omar Berrada over strengthening the squad this month, despite the club finding themselves in a position to achieve their target of qualifying for the Champions League.

"The transfer window is not going to change, we have no conversation to have any change in the squad," said Amorim. "There is a process, there is an idea, we are near the places of Champions League, but we're also near eight teams behind us, so let’s focus on the next game."
Amorim cut a more despondent figure over transfers than in recent weeks. Speaking on December 20, he had sounded more upbeat over the chances of adding to the squad this month.

"We will see. The only thing we know is we will only try to bring players that we think are going to be the future," he said that day. "It’s not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON, it’s not going to be like that.

"Even if we try to bring one player, maybe it’s not the position that we need more. We will try to bring now, and [at] the end of the season, players that are perfect for our future. So, I don’t know what is going to happen, but it is possible that we can do something."

Amorim also stressed that nobody had asked to leave the club this month, despite Roma showing strong interest in Joshua Zirkzee, while Kobbie Mainoo is open to a loan move having struggled for regular football this season. Asked if anyone had knocked on his door to ask to leave, Amorim siad: "No, none of them. I don’t expect them to come to me to ask [to leave]."

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim gives Manchester United injury update ahead of Leeds fixture
body: Ruben Amorim isn't expecting any of Manchester United's injured players to return to the fold against Leeds on Sunday as he prepares to put his faith in youth once again. Harry Maguire hasn't played since November 8 due to a thigh injury and Matthijs de Ligt has been missing for six weeks with a back problem.

Kobbie Mainoo has missed nearly two weeks of action with a calf injury, and Mason Mount was withdrawn at half-time against Newcastle on Boxing Day. Bruno Fernandes injured his hamstring against Aston Villa and is still sidelined, while United are already without Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo, with Morocco, Ivory Coast and Cameroon into the knockout stages of the Africa Cup of Nations.

Amorim confirmed there were no new injury concerns for his squad, but ahead of a final training session on Saturday before the trip to Elland Road, he didn't expect any players to return. "No issues, we’re going to see tomorrow, I don’t think anyone is going to recover," he said.

United face an in-form Leeds side, who are now six games unbeaten after earning a New Year's Day point at Anfield despite resting Dominic Calvert-Lewin and Noah Okafor. Amorim admitted the pace in Daniel Farke's side could cause his team some problems.

"They have a lot of pace and sometimes we struggle with pace," he said. "We prove that we can win any game in any situation in every context. We will try to do that. We know they change the system; the last game they rotated two players who are usually the starters. Good players, and a good manager.

"I heard that it’s a big derby, great environment, big rivalry, but every game in the Premier League is so tough. It’s one more game, I know it means a lot to the fans but we need to go there and try to win."

Amorim turned to teenagers Jack Fletcher and Bendito Mantato off the bench against Wolves earlier this week and might have to use the kids once again, despite the hostile atmosphere United are likely to face across the Pennines.

"We look to everything, but they need to be prepared," he said. "You can see the squad, it’s impossible to stretch the players we don’t have. I try to put a team ready to cope with that and read the game to help them.
"They have to [be ready]. It’s a game in a hostile environment, but they need to experience that. It’s going to be hard for every player, even players with lots of experience."

This will be Amorim's first trip to Elland Road and his first taste of the rivalry between United and Leeds. He has experienced similar fixtures in Portugal as a player for Benfica and coach of Sporting, but expects this to be different.

"I never experienced this one. In Portugal it [Benfica vs Sporting] is a big rivalry, different environment, different culture. The noise is going to be big, it’s hard to compare different cultures, different derbies, let’s just focus on the derby, we will try to win.

"When you play for Manchester United you need to be ready for everything and you guys have the best league in the world. You see every week there are a lot of draws, you never control, never understand, it’s going to be tough but it’s tough every week in the Premier League."

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United transfer stance on Toby Collyer after loan recall decision
body: Toby Collyer is set to be fit before the end of January, but the midfielder could remain at Manchester United for the rest of the season, rather than being loaned out again. The 21-year-old was officially recalled from his loan with Championship side West Brom on New Year's Day, but he has been at Carrington since the end of November after suffering a calf injury with the Baggies.

Collyer struggled for game time before suffering his injury setback, starting just three Championship games and making 12 appearances in total. After sustaining his injury, he has been undergoing rehabilitation with his parent club. He could have returned to the Hawthorns when fit, but United have made the decision to recall him from a planned season-long loan due to concerns over his playing time in the Midlands, as well as his injury issue.

The former Brighton youngster is expected to be fit again by the end of this month, having not featured competitively since sustaining a calf injury during West Brom’s 1-1 draw with Birmingham City in late November.
Collyer will be monitored now that he is back at United and could stay at the club for the remainder of the season if Ruben Amorim decides to keep him as part of the first-team squad.

The midfielder has made 13 appearances for United, 10 of which came under Amorim last season. Although United will have a light schedule in the second half of the season, there is uncertainty over the futures of Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo in the January transfer window, with both attracting loan interest.

If Collyer plays for United this month, it would prohibit another loan move, as players can only play for two clubs during a season. If he doesn't feature, then another loan switch to play first-team football remains an option.
United face an injury crisis in midfield at the moment, but Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes are expected to be fit this month.

headline: MARSHALL: What to expect from Manchester United in the January transfer window - Mainoo, Semenyo and more
body: In an ideal world, Manchester United would have already started their January transfer window with a bang. They were one of several clubs that were keen to sign Antoine Semenyo from Bournemouth, and although that ship hasn't yet sailed, it is now looking unlikely.

Semenyo is set to leave Bournemouth this month, and United would have paid his £65million release clause, but as it stands, it looks like Manchester City are set to win the battle for the 25-year-old. United were strongly in the race, however.

Rather than focusing on a signing to strengthen the attack, this approach for Semenyo was for United to bring forward the pursuit of a long-term target because he was going to be on the move now. It is a theme which is set to condition their January window.
If Semenyo does opt for the Etihad, United won't switch attention to plan B. There isn't a desperate desire to improve the attack in this window.

If anything, it is the midfield which needs work, and a deal there could depend on outgoings. United are planning a significant overhaul in the centre of the pitch this year, although they will be happy to wait until the summer window to kickstart that process.

Bruno Fernandes has started the ball rolling on speculation around his own future again, although he won't be going anywhere this month. The same is true of Casemiro, who is out of contract in the summer. Manuel Ugarte is wanted by Galatasaray but is currently back in the team and unlikely to depart.

The biggest story of the month is therefore likely to be Kobbie Mainoo, who wants to leave on loan to play regular football, having failed to start a Premier League game under Amorim this season. Napoli are keen to take the 20-year-old until the end of the season.
Mainoo is due back from a calf injury shortly and his departure wouldn't be considered while Fernandes is out with a hamstring injury and Amad and Bryan Mbeumo are at the Africa Cup of Nations.

Amorim has made it clear he wants the academy graduate to stay and fight for his place and a loan move later in January might depend on whether the change in formation presents him with more opportunities and if Mainoo pushes to go. If he does, United might have to consider a move for a midfielder, although premium targets such as Carlos Baleba, Adam Wharton and Elliot Anderson will likely be out of reach in January.

There could also be an exit for Joshua Zirkzee in January. Roma remain keen on the Dutch forward and are looking to put together a loan move that could include an option to buy. Zirkzee is only likely to be allowed to move once Amad and Mbeumo return from AFCON.

There is also likely to be a January move for Tyrell Malacia, who was part of the bomb squad in the summer but was unable to find a new club. He made his first appearance in 11 months against Newcastle but will be made available this month.

headline: Jean-Philippe Mateta transfer no-brainer for Man United - but there's a catch
body: When Joshua Zirkzee was substituted at half time in the recent draw against Wolverhampton Wanderers, despite scoring, it was perhaps a sign of just where his Manchester United career is at this moment. The Dutchman is clearly on borrowed time at Old Trafford and with AS Roma sniffing around him, there is every chance he leaves in January.

The only issue with that is it would leave United short in the attack. Currently, their only recognised centre-forward is Benjamin Sesko. Zirkzee, on paper, is also a centre-forward but it has been proven time and again he plays much better when not asked to lead the line.

The only alternative then would be young Chido Obi but the teenager is far from being ready for the first-team limelight. That means United would need to add a striker to their squad should Zirkzee leave but this is, of course, easier said than done.

Any striker worth their salt should be unattainable in the January transfer window. Forward Antoine Semenyo was the exception to the rule but that ship appears to have sailed for the Reds with Manchester City closing on his signature. So where could United look to turn?

One option, according to reports, is Crystal Palace centre-forward Jean-Philippe Mateta. The Frenchman, if available, would be a brilliant addition to the United squad. As the summer transfer window proved, United are looking to sign players who, in Jason Wilcox's own words, could plug and play in the Premier League.

Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha fit that bill perfectly and have arguably been two of United's best performers this season. Mateta would be a transfer straight out of that playbook and considering how much of a nuisance he has been for the Eagles against United, few would complain about him moving to Old Trafford.

At Selhurst Park, he produced one of the more commanding centre-forward displays United have faced this season. Matthijs de Ligt, who has been so dependable for Ruben Amorim this season, really struggled against Mateta.

That's not to mention how he is already familiar with the 3-4-2-1 system so adapting to what Amorim would ask of him should be straightforward. There is a catch though and it is to do with his price tag.

Reports suggested in the summer Palace rejected bids in the region of £50m from Champions League clubs to keep him. Such a price tag is what United will now expect to pay in January or in the summer for Mateta if they do not need to add a striker to their ranks this winter.

That valuation, for a player who turns 29 in June is too much and not how Ineos would look to spend their transfer budget available to them. So, if United are to sign Mateta, they would need to negotiate that figure down significantly.

Experience in the Premier League does cost money and United are crying out for some of it in their forward line. Sesko has plenty of potential but he needs someone who he can share responsibilities with.
But splashing £50m on a player with little to no resale value is not the answer and thus this no-brainer transfer could be out of their hands in January.

headline: MARSHALL: Four transfers Manchester United must make in January window - and why
body: Ruben Amorim is keen for Manchester United to strengthen their squad in January, but he has made the conditions of any deal clear. It's why this window may well pass without anything happening.

The Portuguese head coach has readily talked about the "mistakes" of the past when it comes to recruitment and it's why he's keen to avoid any short-term deals this month if possible. The names of Odion Ighalo and Wout Weghorst spring to mind when considering January windows of the past.

But there's no doubt United have put themselves in a position where it might be wise to roll the dice this month. They are firmly in the battle for a Champions League place next season, an outcome that could be crucial in accelerating their progress under Amorim.

Their form hasn't always been convincing, but it's been good enough to show signs of improvement from last season and with inconsistencies clear beyond the top three of Arsenal, Manchester City and Aston Villa, there is an opportunity there.
Speaking before United's defeat at Villa in December, Amorim said the club would try to do business this month, but that the focus would be on recruiting players who can have a long-term influence.

"We’ll see. The only thing that we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think that is going to be the future. It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON," he said.

"It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that is more that we need more. We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that is part that they are perfect for our future.
"So I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."

When Amorim made those comments, it pointed towards a January move for Antoine Semenyo, whose £65million release clause at Bournemouth has made his mid-season exit a formality. United were keen on a deal but it looks like the 25-year-old is set for a move to Manchester City instead.

The fact that United wanted to sign an attacker in Semenyo but had no alternative in that position explains their January strategy. This was an opportunity that presented itself, rather than fixing a desperate need within the squad.

However, if there is an area that needs strengthening this month, it is in midfield, especially with Bruno Fernandes currently sidelined. There are question marks over the future of all of Fernandes, Manuel Ugarte, Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo.

United are keen to overhaul their midfield in the summer and will move for at least two new players, with Carlos Baleba, Adam Wharton and Elliot Anderson all of interest to them. There appears to be little chance of any coming this month, although Baleba has had a difficult campaign at Brighton.

Instead, United's best approach in midfield might be looking at a more low-key signing, but still someone who will have a part to play beyond the end of this season. Ruben Neves could be available from Al-Hilal and they have monitored Bournemouth duo Tyler Adams and Alex Scott.

With Casemiro out of contract in the summer, Mainoo struggling for minutes under Amorim, Ugarte falling out of favour and Fernandes making noises about his own future, it could yet turn into a year for a significant overhaul in central midfield, so making a start on that in January might be wise.

There are likely to be exits this month as well. Joshua Zirkzee has featured in all of the last seven Premier League games, but he is struggling to make an impact and Roma are very keen on doing a deal for him. If that is either a permanent deal or includes an obligation to buy, then it makes sense, as it's hard to see the Dutchman surviving for much longer at Old Trafford.

Tyrell Malacia made his first appearance for United in 11 months on Boxing Day, but his days also appear to be numbered. The reversion to a back four could theoretically give him more opportunities, but Luke Shaw can play that role, as could Patrick Dorgu, while Diogo Dalot and Noussair Mazraoui can fill in. Malacia was in the bomb squad in the summer and needs a move this month.

Then there is Mainoo. The 20-year-old has suffered an untimely calf injury at a point when he might well have finally started a game this season. Amorim reverted to a three-man midfield against Newcastle and that opens up more chances for the academy graduate.

Mainoo isn't expected to be out for long and Amorim has urged him to stay and fight for his place. However, Mainoo needs to play more football than the 212 Premier League minutes he has managed this season. His development has stalled while the likes of Baleba, Wharton and Anderson have surpassed him. The only way to change that is by playing.

As unpalatable as it might be, if his fortunes don't change then he should be sent on loan in January. Napoli are keen to sign him and six months playing in a Serie A title race and in the Champions League, while being coached by Antonio Conte, could be a vital spell in his development.
